MINUTE ORDER (text only) authorized by Judge Lauren King. Counsel for Defendants left a voicemail with the Courtroom Deputy inquiring about the status of Docket Number 100 . Under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68(a), the clerk must enter judgment "[i]f, within 14 days after being served, the opposing party serves written notice accepting the offer" and "either party... file[s] the offer and notice of acceptance, plus proof of service," with the Court. Here, the parties have submitted no evidence that Plaintiff accepted the amended offer in accordance with Rule 68(a). To the extent the parties intend to resolve this matter through Rule 68, the clerk will enter judgment when the Court receives a submission compliant with Rule 68(a). (NAW) (Entered: 05/11/2023)

case_data.name: Davey v. Pierce County Council
case_data.plaintiff_description: A person detained pre-trial at Pierce County Jail in Washington
case_data.summary:
This case involves allegations of inhumane conditions in Washington's Pierce County Jail relating to plumbing problems and sewage backups.

This lawsuit was initiated on January 25, 2021 when plaintiff filed a pro se complaint in the US District Court for the Western District of Washington against Pierce County and individuals at the Pierce County Sheriff’s Department. (The complaint was filed on behalf of two plaintiffs, but the court later dismissed one and ordered each to file their own individual claims). The plaintiff sued under 42 USC § 1983, alleging that conditions in the Mental Health Unit of the Pierce County Jail relating to plumbing and sewer conditions violated the 14th Amendment's Due Process Clause and the 8th Amendment's prohibition on cruel and unusual punishment. The plaintiff also brought claims under Washington state law. 

Specifically, the plaintiff alleged that he was being held in inhumane and dangerously unsanitary conditions due to the constant smell of urine and feces caused by sewage backup and other sanitation issues. Plaintiff also alleged that the staff failed to provide adequate cleaning and personal protective equipment and generally ignored complaints. He sought declaratory relief, an injunction, and compensatory and punitive damages. The case was assigned to District Judge John C. Coughenour.

On March 31, 2021, the plaintiff moved for appointment of counsel. Plaintiff filed an amended complaint on April 20, 2021. The following month, on May 24, Magistrate Judge S. Kate Vaughn denied plaintiff’s motion to appoint counsel. In June 2021, defendants filed a motion to dismiss for failure to state a claim and, alternatively, to change venue.

Plaintiff filed a motion for leave to file another amended complaint on December 21, 2021. On that same day, the case was reassigned to District Judge Lauren King.

On March 10, 2022, Magistrate Judge Vaughn issued a R&R that recommended partially granting both defendants’ motion to dismiss and plaintiff’s motion for leave to file a second amended complaint. 2022 WL 2791521. Specifically, Magistrate Judge Vaughn recommended denying Defendants' motion to dismiss and granting plaintiff’s motion to amend with respect to the plaintiff's constitutional claims against certain specific defendants in their individual capacities. However, the magistrate judge recommended dismissing individual constitutional claims against other named defendants where the claims were based on a theory of vicarious liability. Magistrate Judge Vaughn also recommended granting plaintiff's motion to amend and denying defendants’ motion to dismiss with respect to the constitutional claims against the County, claims against all the individual named defendants in their official capacities, and the state law claims. Magistrate Vaughn also recommended denying defendant’s motion to change venue. This report was adopted by Judge King on July 15, 2022. 2022 WL 2789010. On the same day, the plaintiff filed his second amended complaint.

On August 8, 2022, Magistrate Judge Vaughn reconsidered plaintiffs request for appointment of counsel and granted it because the plaintiff's claims had largely survived the motion to dismiss. 2022 WL 3155368. 

The parties subsequently settled the case. On May 30, 2023, the court directed the clerk to enter judgment in favor of Plaintiff for $33,000 plus an additional $12,000 in fees and costs. The case is now closed. However, the plaintiff filed a subsequent lawsuit in 2023, alleging that the sanitation conditions at the jail were still unconstitutional and seeking to represent a class of people detained at the jail.
case_data.summary_short: On March 31, 2021, a civilly committed pre-trial detainee filed this lawsuit in the Western District of Washington at Tacoma, against Pierce County and named individuals at the Pierce County Sheriffโs Department, alleging inhumane living conditions caused by plumbing problems and sewer conditions in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments, as well as state law. The plaintiff initially proceeded pro se, but was ultimately appointed counsel by the court in 2022.  The parties reached a settlement agreement in 2023 for $33,000 plus $12,000 in fees and costs. The case is now closed.

documents.title: Order
documents.text:
Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV   Document 103   Filed 05/30/23   Page 1 of 3
 
1 
2 
3 
4 
5 
6 
7 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
8 
WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
AT TACOMA 
9 
10 
JUSTIN ALLEN DAVEY,  CASE NO. 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV 
11 
  Plaintiff,  ORDER  
12 
  v. 
13 
PIERCE COUNTY COUNCIL et al., 
14 
  Defendants. 
15 
 
16  Before the Court is the Declaration of Frank A. Cornelius, submitting a May 15, 2023 email 
17  from  counsel  for  Plaintiff  Justin  Allen  Davey  (also  known  as  Echota  Wolfclan),  offering 
18  โadditional confirmation that Plaintiff has timely accepted Defendantsโ March 9, 2023 Amended 
19  Offer of Judgment[.]โ Dkt. No. 102 at 4; see Dkt. No. 100 (Defendantsโ Amended Offer of 
20  Judgment). Plaintiffโs counsel further states that โ[i]t was Plaintiffโs intention that the March 7, 
21  2023 Joint Statement . . . serve as notice and confirmation that Plaintiff had accepted Defendantsโ 
22  offer to settle for $33,000 plus $12,000 in fees and costs, which was then reflected in the Amended 
23  Offer of Judgment filed on March 9, 2023[.]โ Dkt. No. 102 at 4; see Dkt. No. 99 (partiesโ Joint 
24  Statement dated March 7, 2023).  
 
ORDER - 1 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV   Document 103   Filed 05/30/23   Page 2 of 3
 
1  Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68(a) provides that if a party serves written notice 
2  accepting an offer of judgment within 14 days after being served, โeither party may then file the 
3  offer and notice of acceptance, plus proof of service.โ If this process is followed, the Clerk โmust 
4  then enter judgment.โ Fed. R. Civ. P. 68(a).  
5  Here, the parties have followed a convoluted process. On March 1, 2023, Defendants filed 
6  a โNotice of Acceptanceโ of their offer of judgment. See Dkt. Nos. 96, 97-1. However, because 
7  the offer appeared to exclude costs from the judgment, the Court considered it invalid. Dkt. No. 
8  98. The Court accordingly ordered that the parties either submit supplemental briefs clarifying 
9  whether  they  intended  that  the  Court  award  costs  or  else  โrevoke  and  redo  the  offer  and 
10  acceptance.โ Dkt. No. 98 at 3. The next day, the parties submitted a joint statement indicating that 
11  they had agreed to settle the matter for โ$33,000 plus $12,000.00 for costs and attorneysโ feesโ on 
12  March 3, 2023, and that they would โfile an updated Offer of Judgmentโ reflecting those amounts. 
13  Dkt. No. 99 at 1. On March 9, Defendants filed an Amended Offer of Judgment that specified that 
14  the offer was for $33,000 plus โan additional Twelve Thousand Dollars ($12,000.00) in costs and 
15  fees[.]โ Dkt. No. 100 at 1. No acceptance followed.  
16  On May 11, 2023, after Counsel for Defendants left a voicemail with the Courtroom 
17  Deputy inquiring about the status of Docket Number 100, the Court issued an Order reminding the 
18  parties that Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 68(a) requires the clerk to enter judgment only โ[i]f, 
19  within 14 days after being served, the opposing party serves written notice accepting the offer,โ 
20  and that โthe parties ha[d] submitted no evidence that Plaintiff accepted the amended offer in 
21  accordance with Rule 68(a).โ Dkt. No. 101 (emphasis added). On May 26, Defendants filed a May 
22  15, 2023 email from Plaintiffโs counsel to Defendants stating that Plaintiff intended to accept 
23  Defendantsโ March 9, 2023 amended offer (Dkt. No. 100) via the March 7, 2023 joint statement 
24  (Dkt. No. 99). Dkt. No. 102 at 4.  
 
ORDER - 2 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV   Document 103   Filed 05/30/23   Page 3 of 3
 
1  This muddy record is less than ideal. The March 7 joint statement, which indicated that the 
2  parties โw[ould] file an updated Offer of Judgment,โ Dkt. No. 99 at 1, cannot count as an 
3  acceptance of the forthcoming March 9, 2023 offer under Rule 68(a). However, the record reflects 
4  that Defendants sent Plaintiff a written offer encompassing the two sums on March 3, 2023, and 
5  that Plaintiff subsequently accepted that offer in writing by March 7, 2023 at the latest. Dkt. No. 
6  99 at 1 (March 7, 2023 joint statement that โthe parties agreed to a settlement of all costs, including 
7  attorneysโ fees, in the amount of $12,000.00โ in addition to the $33,000 reflected in Docket 
8  Number 97-1). The Court construes the partiesโ filings together to constitute sufficient evidence 
9  of an offer of judgment, subsequent written acceptance within 14 days, and proof of service. 
10  Accordingly, the Court DIRECTS the Clerk to enter judgment in Plaintiffโs favor in the 
11  amount of $33,000 plus an additional $12,000 in fees and costs. See Dkt. Nos. 100; 102.  
12   
13  Dated this 30th day of May, 2023. 
14  A     
15  Lauren King
United States District Judge 
16

18

22 
23 
24 
 
ORDER - 3

documents.title: Order Reconsidering Request for Appointment of Counsel and Directing Pro Bono Coordinator to Identify Pro Bono Counsel
documents.text:
Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV   Document 73   Filed 08/08/22   Page 1 of 3
 
1 
2 
3 
4 
5 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
6 
WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
AT SEATTLE 
7 
8  JUSTIN ALLEN DAVEY, 
9    Plaintiff,  Case No. C21-05068-JCC-SKV 
10    v.  ORDER RECONSIDERING REQUEST 
FOR APPOINTMENT OF COUNSEL 
11  PIERCE COUNTY COUNCIL, et al.,  AND DIRECTING PRO BONO 
COORDINATOR TO IDENTIFY PRO 
  Defendant.  BONO COUNSEL 
12 
13 
 
14  This is a 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 prisoner civil rights action.  Plaintiff previously moved for 
15  appointment of counsel.  Dkt. 24.  The Court previously denied that motion without prejudice.  
16  Dkt. 31.  For the reasons below, the Court hereby sua sponte reconsiders Plaintiffโs request for 
17  appointment of counsel and concludes that extraordinary circumstances now support the 
18  appointment of counsel in this case.  Plaintiffโs request for appointment of counsel, Dkt. 24, is 
19  granted as provided below.  
20  Generally, the decision to appoint pro bono counsel rests within โthe sound discretion of 
21  the trial court and is granted only in exceptional circumstances.โ  Agyeman v. Corrections Corp. 
22  of America, 390 F.3d 1101, 1103 (9th Cir. 2004).  A finding of exceptional circumstances 
23  requires an evaluation of both the likelihood of success on the merits and the ability of the 
 
ORDER RECONSIDERING REQUEST FOR 
APPOINTMENT OF COUNSEL AND DIRECTING 
 
PRO BONO COORDINATOR TO IDENTIFY PRO 
BONO COUNSEL - 1 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV   Document 73   Filed 08/08/22   Page 2 of 3
 
1  plaintiff to articulate his or her claims pro se in light of the complexity of the legal issues 
2  involved.  Terrell v. Brewer, 935 F.2d 1015, 1017 (9th Cir. 1991) (citations omitted).  Neither of 
3  these factors is dispositive, and the factors must be viewed together before reaching a decision 
4  regarding appointment of counsel.  Wilborn v. Escalderon, 789 F.2d 1328, 1331 (9th Cir. 1986). 
5  Plaintiff previously moved for appointment of counsel shortly after commencing this 
6  action.  Dkt. 24.  The Court denied the motion at that time finding that, because Plaintiffโs 
7  amended complaint had just been served and Defendants had not yet filed an answer, it was too 
8  early in the case to assess Plaintiffโs likelihood of success on the merits.  Dkt. 31.  The Court also 
9  found that, at that early stage, the Court could not conclude that Plaintiffโs claims, that 
10  Defendants failed to properly address allegedly unsanitary conditions due to sewage backups in 
11  Plaintiffโs unit at Pierce County Jail, were particularly complex.  Id.  The Court further found 
12  that, at that early stage of the case, Plaintiff had demonstrated an adequate ability to articulate his 
13  claims pro se.  Id.   
14  Since the order denying Plaintiffโs request for counsel, the litigation has advanced, and 
15  circumstances have changed.  While the Court cannot, at this time, definitely determine 
16  Plaintiffโs ultimate likelihood of success on the merits, the vast majority of his claims have now 
17  survived a motion to dismiss.  See Dkt. 71.  Furthermore, completing discovery and litigating the 
18  merits of Plaintiffโs conditions of confinement claims is likely to significantly increase the 
19  complexity of the litigation process, may require the ability to investigate the status of the 
20  plumbing and sewage system at Pierce County Jail, and potentially the ability to consult an 
21  expert or develop expert evidence.  Accordingly, the Court finds that Plaintiff has at this time 
22  demonstrated a sufficient potential for success on the merits and that, in light of the increasing 
23 
 
ORDER RECONSIDERING REQUEST FOR 
APPOINTMENT OF COUNSEL AND DIRECTING 
 
PRO BONO COORDINATOR TO IDENTIFY PRO 
BONO COUNSEL - 2 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV   Document 73   Filed 08/08/22   Page 3 of 3
 
1  complexity of the litigation process at this stage, Plaintiff will face increasing challenges 
2  litigating and articulating his claims pro se.   
3  The Court notes that Plaintiff has also asserted he faces additional difficulty litigating his 
4  case pro se due to his mental illness.  Dkt. 24.  While not dispositive on its own as there is 
5  limited information before the Court regarding the nature and impact of Plaintiffโs mental illness, 
6  considering all of the other factors discussed above, the Court finds that the fact that Plaintiff 
7  asserts he has a mental illness that may have the potential to affect his ability to litigate his case, 
8  also weighs in favor of appointing counsel.  Accordingly, the Court concludes that this case 
9  presents extraordinary circumstances that support the appointment of counsel pursuant to 28 
10  U.S.C. ยง 1915. 
11  CONCLUSION AND DIRECTIONS TO CLERK 
12  Upon reconsideration, Plaintiffโs request for appointment of counsel, Dkt. 24, is granted, 
13  contingent on the identification of counsel willing to represent Plaintiff in this matter.  The 
14  Western District of Washingtonโs pro bono coordinator is directed to identify counsel to 
15  represent Plaintiff, in accordance with the Courtโs General Order 16-20 (โIn re: Amended Plan 
16  for the Representation of Pro Se Litigants in Civil Rights Actionsโ), section 4.  Once it has been 
17  determined whether the Court will be able to appoint an attorney to represent Plaintiff, the Court 
18  will issue appropriate orders.  
19  The Clerk shall send a copy of this order to Plaintiff, counsel for Defendants, the pro 
20  bono coordinator, and the Honorable Lauren King.  
21  Dated this 8th day of August, 2022. 
22 
   
A
23 
S. KATE VAUGHAN 
United States Magistrate Judge 
 
ORDER RECONSIDERING REQUEST FOR 
APPOINTMENT OF COUNSEL AND DIRECTING 
 
PRO BONO COORDINATOR TO IDENTIFY PRO 
BONO COUNSEL - 3

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 1 of 35
 
1 
2 
3 
4 
5 
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
6 
WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON 
AT TACOMA 
7 
8  JUSTIN ALLEN DAVEY, 
9    Plaintiff,  Case No. C21-05068-LK-SKV 
10    v.  REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION 
11  PIERCE COUNTY COUNCIL, et al., 
  Defendant. 
12 
13 
 
14 
Plaintiff, Justin Allen Davey, proceeds pro se and in forma pauperis in this 42 U.S.C. ยง 
15 
1983 civil rights action.  Plaintiff was a county detainee at Pierce County Jail at the time he 
16 
commenced this action.  See Dkts. 26, 53-2.  Plaintiffโs amended complaint challenges the 
17 
constitutionality of the conditions of his confinement while he was detained at Pierce County Jail 
18 
for approximately seven months, beginning in or around May of 2020.  Dkt. 26.  Currently 
19 
pending before the Court are Defendantsโ motion to dismiss the amended complaint and to 
20 
change venue (Dkts. 33, 47), and Plaintiffโs motion for leave to file a second amended complaint 
21 
(Dkt. 53).  Plaintiff opposes Defendantsโ motion to dismiss (Dkts. 39), and Defendants oppose 
22 
Plaintiffโs motion to amend (Dkt. 60). 
23 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 1 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 2 of 35
 
1  The Court has considered Defendantsโ motion to dismiss together with and in light of 
2  Plaintiffโs motion to amend and the proposed second amended complaint and has considered all 
3  of the briefing submitted with respect to the motions and the balance of the record.  Having done 
4  so, the Court recommends that Defendantsโ motion to dismiss (Dkts. 33, 47) and Plaintiffโs 
5  motion for leave to file a second amended complaint (Dkt. 53) be granted in part and denied in 
6  part and that Defendantsโ motion to change venue (Dkt. 30) be denied.   
7  BACKGROUND 
8  Plaintiff commenced this action on or about January 25, 2021.  Dkt. 1.  In his amended 
9  complaint filed April 20, 2021, Plaintiff alleges that plumbing and sewer conditions in his unit 
10  (Mental Health Unit 3 North A) at Pierce County Jail caused sewage backups in the toilets in his 
11  cells and ongoing serious sanitation issues.  Dkt. 26.  Plaintiffโs amended complaint indicates that 
12  he was a pretrial detainee at the time of the events giving rise to his claims and alleges that the 
13  conditions of confinement at the Jail violated his Fourteenth Amendment due process rights.  Id. at 
14  11-12.  Plaintiffโs amended complaint names as Defendants: Pierce County/Pierce County Council; 
15  Ed Troyer, Sheriff of Pierce County; Patti Jackson, Chief of the Internal Operation of the Pierce 
16  County Sheriff Dept. Correction Bureau; B. Sutherlin, Captain Deputy Corrections Officer at the 
17  Pierce County Sheriffโs Department; Dobson, Lieutenant Deputy Corrections Officer at the Pierce 
18  County Sheriffโs Department; Mastandrea, Sergeant Deputy Corrections Officer at the Pierce 
19  County Sheriffโs Department; D. Herbison, Sergeant Deputy Corrections Officer at the Pierce 
20  County Sheriffโs Department; and, T. Pearson, Deputy Corrections Officer at the Pierce County 
21  Sheriffโs Department.1  Dkt. 26, at 4-10.  Plaintiff names all non-entity Defendants in their 
22  individual and official capacities.  Id. 
23   
1 Defendantsโ motion to dismiss identifies the full names of several of the Defendants as Brian Sutherlin, 
  Matthew Dobson, Anthony Mastandrea, Darryl Herbison, and Torvald Pearson.  See Dkt. 33. 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 2 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 3 of 35
 
1  Defendants moved to dismiss Plaintiffโs amended complaint arguing primarily that 
2  Plaintiff failed to allege sufficient facts to state a claim against the Defendants under either the 
3  Eighth or Fourteenth Amendment standard based upon the conditions of his confinement at the 
4  Jail.2  Dkts. 33, 47.  Defendants also alternatively moved to change venue.  Dkt. 33.  Plaintiff 
5  subsequently moved to amend his complaint.  Dkt. 53.  Plaintiffโs proposed second amended 
6  complaint includes additional facts in support of his existing claims as well as new claims 
7  alleging negligence under Washington state law, violation of the Washington State Constitution, 
8  and violation of the Eighth Amendment during the period of a few days when Plaintiffโs status 
9  had changed to that of a post-conviction prisoner.  Dkt. 53-2.  Defendants oppose Plaintiffโs 
10  motion to amend on the grounds that the amendment is futile, arguing that Plaintiffโs proposed 
11  second amended complaint still fails to state a claim.  Dkts. 55, 60.  Defendants primarily rely on 
12  the same arguments they advance in their motion to dismiss, which highlight alleged deficiencies 
13  in the factual allegations in Plaintiffโs amended complaint and argue that Plaintiffโs proposed 
14  second amended complaint fails to cure those deficiencies.  Id. 
15  In the proposed second amended complaint, Plaintiff names the same Defendants but, as 
16  noted, includes additional facts and claims.  Dkt. 53-2.  Plaintiff again names all non-entity 
17  Defendants in their individual and official capacities.  Id.  He also clarifies that he was a pretrial 
18  detainee during the vast majority of the period at issue, from May 12, 2020 to March 12, 2021, 
19  and a post-conviction prisoner from March 12, 2021 to March 16, 2021.  Id.  Plaintiff alleges that 
20 
 
2 As discussed below, the Eighth Amendment prohibits the cruel and unusual punishment of prisoners, 
21 
while the punishment of pretrial detainees is prohibited by the Fourteenth Amendment.  See Bell v. 
Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 535 (1979) (โ[U]nder the Due Process Clause, a detainee may not be punished 
22 
prior to an adjudication of guilt in accordance with due process of law.โ).  The Court notes that 
Defendantsโ original motion to dismiss largely addressed Plaintiffโs claims under the Eighth Amendment 
23  standard.  See Dkt. 33.  Accordingly, at the Courtโs direction, Defendants submitted additional briefing 
addressing Plaintiffโs claims under the Fourteenth Amendment standard in light of Plaintiffโs apparent 
  status as a pretrial detainee during the majority of the period in question.  See Dkts. 44, 47. 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 3 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 4 of 35
 
1  on May 12, 2020, he was reclassified from Level 2 Mental Health Housing unit to Level 3 
2  Mental Health Housing Unit (3 North A), which he indicates is a place where mentally ill 
3  detainees are placed mostly while awaiting competency evaluations.  Id. at 10.  He alleges when 
4  he arrived his cell was in a โdangerousโ condition in that there was human waste on the toilet 
5  seat, vomit, spit, mucus on floor, and the stench of feces and urine.  Id.  He indicates he was 
6  given a spray bottle but no PPE (personal protective equipment) and denied a change of clothes 
7  when bodily waste splashed on his clothes and on his hands and that he was forced to wear those 
8  same clothes for two days.  Id.  Plaintiff alleges on May 13, 2020, he noticed his toilet was full of 
9  human waste and that the surrounding area on the floor had splashes of human waste and that he 
10  immediately felt sick and was unable to eat his breakfast.  Id.  He indicates he requested cleaning 
11  supplies but was denied and informed cleaning supplies were handed out during graveyard hours 
12  and that he was forced to use his T-shirt to clean the area.  Id.  He also states he noticed urine and 
13  feces backfilling into the cell toilet from the cell next to his.  Id., at 11.  He states that every time 
14  the adjoining cell toilet flushed, raw sewage would back up and nearly overflow splashing onto 
15  the wall and floors, and that this occurred 10-15 times daily.  Id.   
16  Plaintiff alleges that on May 13, 2020, there was a โformal inspectionโ which he indicates 
17  occurred every three weeks and was a day when different ranking officers (Captain, Lieutenant, 
18  and Sergeant) would come to the unit to make sure the facility was working and was also an 
19  opportunity for inmates to verbally communicate direct problems with higher ranking officers.  
20  Id.  At the May 13 formal inspection, Plaintiff indicates he told the โCaptainโ and โLieutenantโ3 
21  about the condition of his cell the previous day and showed them that the โbodily fluidsโ were 
22 
 
3 Plaintiff does not specifically identify the Captain and Lieutenant here by name but, construing 
23  Plaintiffโs second amended complaint liberally, and based upon later references to the โCaptainโ and 
โLieutenantโ, the Court interprets Plaintiffโs complaint to refer here to Defendants Captain Sutherlin and 
  Lieutenant Dobson. 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 4 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 5 of 35
 
1  not leaving the unit and that when the toilet flushed in the adjoining cell the waste would back up 
2  into his cell toilet.  Id.  He indicates that the Captain and Lieutenant took notes and said they 
3  would call and check on the issue but that, apparently, they did not do so because maintenance 
4  did not come.  Id.   
5  Plaintiff alleges that thereafter nearly every day Jail cluster officers denied him cleaning 
6  supplies and PPE to clean contaminated areas after his toilet backfilled in his cell and that he was 
7  left to clean with his own T-shirts and sink water.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates he asked mental health 
8  social workers to move him due to increased psychiatric problems including hallucinations, 
9  anxiety and fear of contracting disease but that he was mostly ignored and told it was โan old 
10  building.โ  Id.   
11  Plaintiff alleges that on May 18, 2020, he was moved to cell 25 where he found the toilet 
12  saturated with feces and urine and the stench of sitting urine and feces.  Id.  He claims he was 
13  again denied cleaning supplies by officers and forced to use his own clothes to clean areas.  Id. at 
14  12.  He indicates that although he was placed in difference cells in 3 North A he experienced the 
15  same constant sewage backup issues in every cell.  Id.  Plaintiff further claims the unit itself was 
16  saturated from the stench and fumes of raw sewage exploding out of 10 sewage drainage pipes 
17  next to the cell doors causing himself and other residents to endure constant headaches, 
18  vomiting, diarrhea, and inability to eat.  Id.   
19  Plaintiff indicates that on the next formal inspection day, June 3, 2020, he and several 
20  other residents again informed Defendants Sutherlin, Dobson, and Pearson about the sewer 
21  situation.  Id.  He indicates he pleaded with these Defendants to fix the plumbing, informing 
22  them that every time the toilet in a connected cell flushed the bodily waste would back up into 
23  his toilet and splash everywhere and at times overflow and that he was denied cleaning supplies 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 5 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 6 of 35
 
1  and left to clean with his T-shirt.  Id.  He indicates he informed them that every night waste 
2  would back up into the toilets and often overflow onto his cell floor and that he was forced to eat 
3  under these conditions.  Id.  Plaintiff also explained that when using the toilet, the waste from 
4  other prisoners would splash up onto him.  Id.  Plaintiff informed these Defendants that he 
5  believed that these conditions created a substantial risk of infectious, illness and disease and that 
6  the conditions were making him sick and exacerbating his mental illness.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates 
7  that Defendantsโ only response was that this was a โ30-year mistakeโ and that Pierce County 
8  wouldnโt pay for the issue to be fixed so the unit would โjust have to deal with it.โ  Id.  He 
9  indicates that when he complained about staff not giving him cleaning supplies, the Defendants 
10  laughed at him and ignored him.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates he and other residents requested 
11  grievances but were denied by cluster officers and told the issue wasnโt grievable because the 
12  Jail was already aware of the issue. Id. at 13. 
13  On June 16, 2020, Plaintiff indicates he filed a grievance (#530524) under โstaff 
14  treatment of inmates,โ because he was not permitted to grieve about not receiving cleaning 
15  supplies or plumbing issues.  Id.  The grievance related to the refusal of an Officer (โOlsenโ) to 
16  provide Plaintiff with adequate cleaning supplies, specifically a rag, to clean his cell.  Id.  
17  Plaintiff alleges that when sewage splashes on the floor and residents of the unit are denied 
18  cleaning supplies, they are forced to walk on contaminated floors with just socks and slippers 
19  and thereafter pass the sewage from their socks to their beds.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates that from 
20  May 12, 2020, to June 18, 2020, he complained about the conditions of the unit daily to cluster 
21  officers, also noting the presence of insects coming from the sewage drainpipes, and that he was 
22  told by the officers that they werenโt plumbers and couldnโt solve the issue. Id.  Plaintiff 
23 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 6 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 7 of 35
 
1  indicates that during this same period he was only supplied any form of cleaning supplies on two 
2  occasions.  Id. 
3  Plaintiff indicates that on June 18, 2020, he was transferred to competency restoration 
4  services and on September 15, 2020, was transferred back to Pierce County Jail.  Id.  He 
5  indicates on September 16, 2020, he was transferred back to 3 North A and placed in cell 10-11 
6  where he experienced the same issue of sewage backing up into the cell and was again denied 
7  cleaning supplies.  Id.  He alleges these same issues continued thereafter.  Id. at 14.  Plaintiff 
8  alleges he was transferred to cell 18 at some point by mental health social workers and that 
9  during their weekly visits he informed them that he woke up feeling dizzy and not well every 
10  morning because of the plumbing issue.  Id.  He indicates the social workers blamed his 
11  symptoms on his medications but notes he had not experienced these symptoms while on the 
12  same medications and detained at a different facility for restoration services.  Id.    
13  Plaintiff indicates that at formal inspection on October 7, 2020, he complained again of 
14  the conditions to Defendants Sutherlin, Dobson, Pearson, and this time also to Defendant 
15  Mastandrea, explaining that the sewage and foul odor were making them sick, and mosquitos and 
16  flies were coming from the sewage drains.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates that the Defendants responded 
17  that Pierce County and the Jail were aware of the issue, that it was the way the plumbing was 
18  designed and would not be fixed at that time, and that Plaintiff would just have to deal with it.  
19  Id.  Plaintiff indicates the conditions persisted and that he and other residents were continually 
20  denied requests for grievances.  Id. at 15. 
21  Plaintiff indicates that at formal inspection on October 28, 2020, he again informed 
22  Defendants Sutherlin, Dobson, and Pearson of the conditions and complained of being exposed 
23  to raw sewage.  Id.  Plaintiff states that Defendants again ignored his complaints and that 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 7 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 8 of 35
 
1  Defendant Pearson told him the building was โoldโ and that if he didnโt like being there, he 
2  should โstop coming to jail.โ  Id.   
3  Plaintiff indicates that at formal inspection on November 18, 2020, before he could 
4  complain, Defendants Sutherlin, Dobson, and Pearson told the unit that if anyone brought up 
5  issues that had already been discussed that disciplinary action would be taken and again told unit 
6  residents that they were aware of the plumbing issues and that it was a construction issue and 
7  wouldnโt be addressed at that time.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates that Defendants also informed the unit 
8  that cleaning supplies were not a policy but a privilege for the cluster officers to give at their 
9  disposal.  Id.  Plaintiff further alleges that he was also informed on another occasion that Pierce 
10  County had no specific policy requiring the provision of cleaning supplies to inmates.  Id. 
11  Plaintiff states that on December 13, 2020, a new officer to the unit, Officer Erwin, 
12  provided Plaintiff with cleaning supplies and suggested he kite the duty sergeant if he wanted a 
13  grievance.  Id. at 16.  Plaintiff indicates on December 14, 2020, he submitted a kite asking for a 
14  grievance to submit regarding the unsafe environment caused by the sewer.  Id.  He states that 
15  corrections officer Starks and Defendant Herbison came and asked what the problem was, and he 
16  informed them about the toilets overflowing, denial of cleaning supplies and the constant odor of 
17  raw sewage.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates that later that day corrections officer Starks told Plaintiff to 
18  dump buckets of water down the sewer pipes closets.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates that while he was 
19  dumping water, he noticed dead mice in mouse traps in two of the drainage pipes.  Id.  Plaintiff 
20  also indicates that the practice of dumping water down the drains โdoesnโt work.โ  Id. at 22.  He 
21  indicates that on December 15, 2020, he received a response to his kite from Defendant Herbison 
22  saying that โOfficers are researching the issues. The deputies report โNothing Unusual.โโ  Id. at 
23  16.  Plaintiff indicates he was denied a grievance.  Id.   
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 8 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 9 of 35
 
1  Plaintiff indicates he again requested a grievance to a different duty sergeant and this 
2  time was issued a grievance by Sergeant Ake.  Id. at 17.  Plaintiff also alleges that he filed a 
3  grievance dated December 16, 2020, in which he raised the following issues: his health concern 
4  about the unit toilets; that he had raised the issue at the last four inspections; that the toilets shoot 
5  out other inmateโs feces; that he has to eat in his cell with other peopleโs fecal matter splattered 
6  all over the toilet; that there is a smell throughout the whole unit; that he is forced to clean 
7  contaminated areas without proper PPE; being forced to wait hours for cleaning supplies; that 
8  inmates threaten each other (including himself) because of the plumbing; and requests that the 
9  unit residents be moved until the conditions are made compatible with living.  Id.   
10  Plaintiff indicates on December 18, 2020, a plumber named โJasonโ came and snaked the 
11  toilets and told Plaintiff the toilet wasnโt clogged.  Id.  Plaintiff states he explained the issue of 
12  the toilets backflowing and overflowing into the cell and โJasonโ acknowledged the issue but 
13  said it was a โshitty situationโ and in order to fix it they would have to reconstruct the plumbing 
14  and that Pierce County would not fund it.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates that later that day he received a 
15  response to his grievance from Defendant Mastandrea stating that maintenance checked and 
16  snaked the toilets and that he had spoken to Plaintiff who indicated he was satisfied with 
17  maintenanceโs response and explanation.  Id. at 18.  Plaintiff indicates he never spoke to 
18  Defendant Mastandrea and never said he was โsatisfiedโ with the response.  Id.  Plaintiff 
19  indicates he filed an appeal indicating he had never spoken to Defendant Mastandrea, that he was 
20  not satisfied with the response, and also complaining that there was not response to his 
21  complaints about lack of cleaning supplies or the odors causing physical illness.  Id.  Plaintiff 
22  states that after handing his appeal to the cluster officer it was โnever seen againโ indicating it 
23  was either lost in the transfer or purposely rejected.  Id.   
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 9 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 10 of 35
 
1  In January 2021, Plaintiff indicates he sent medical kites asking to be checked medically 
2  due to the exposure to raw sewage but medical staff responded there was โno medical indication 
3  for this request.โ  Id. at 19.  On January 14, 2021, Plaintiff indicates he was hired as his Units 
4  โunit workerโ and was told he would be given cleaning supplies at 9 p.m. to clean the day room 
5  and shower.  Id.  Plaintiff states he would hide some of the cleaning disinfectant he received in 
6  order to clean his own cell.โ Id.   
7  Plaintiff indicates that at the end of January 2021, he sent kites asking why the appeal of 
8  his grievance had not been heard.  Id.  He indicates on February 2, 2021, he received a response 
9  from Captain Ganga indicating that his office had never received Plaintiffโs appeal.  Id.  Plaintiff 
10  states on February 3, 2021, the Jail went into mandatory quarantine status and residents of the 
11  unit were stuck in their contaminated cells for four days.  Id.  at 20.  Plaintiff indicates on 
12  February 6, 2021, an officer read his ยง 1983 complaint and made copies of it.  Id.  He states on 
13  February 7, 2021, Sergeant Ake and Defendant Mastandrea came and asked Plaintiff what was 
14  โgoing onโ, which he believed to be a reference to his ยง 1983 complaint.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates 
15  he repeated his complaints about the conditions.  Id.  On February 10, 2021, Captain Genga came 
16  to the unit and Plaintiff informed him of the ongoing plumbing issues and denial of cleaning 
17  supplies.  Id. at 21.  Plaintiff alleges Captain Genga indicated he would contact maintenance and 
18  that he would have a staff meeting about getting cleaning supplies to the residents when needed.  
19  Id.   
20  On February 11, 2021, Sergeant Smith brought an email to 3 North A Cluster Officers 
21  that had Chief Patti Jacksonโs name on it.  Id.  Plaintiff indicates the email discussed what 
22  officers were to do and said โmake sure officers flushed the toilets of empty cells.โ  Id.  Plaintiff 
23  indicates between February 2, 2021, and March 16, 2021, the officers did not adhere to 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 10 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 11 of 35
 
1  Defendant Jacksonโs email and cleaning supplies were withheld due to Covid mandatory

14  DISCUSSION 
15  A.  Motion to Dismiss and Motion to Amend 
16  1.  Relevant Legal Standards 
17  a.  Motion to Dismiss 
18  A motion to dismiss can be granted only if Plaintiffโs complaint, with all factual 
19  allegations accepted as true, fails to โraise a right to relief above the speculative level[.]โ  Bell 
20  Atlantic Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 545 (2007).  
21  To survive a motion to dismiss, a complaint must contain sufficient factual matter, 
accepted as true, to โstate a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.โ A claim has 
22  facial plausibility when the plaintiff pleads factual content that allows the court to 
draw the reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged. 
The plausibility standard is not akin to a probability requirement, but it asks for more 
23 
than a sheer possibility that a defendant has acted unlawfully.

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 12 of 35
 
1  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (quoting Twombly, 550 U.S. at 556, 570). 
2  A complaint must contain a โshort and plain statement of the claim showing that the 
3  pleader is entitled to relief.โ  Fed. R. Civ. P. 8(a)(2).  โSpecific facts are not necessary; the 
4  statement need only give the defendant fair notice of what the . . . claim is and the grounds upon 
5  which it rests.โ  Erickson v. Pardus, et al., 551 U.S. 89, 93 (2007) (internal citations omitted). 
6  However, the pleading must be more than an โunadorned, the-defendant-unlawfully-harmed-me 
7  accusation.โ  Iqbal, 556 U.S. at 678.  The Court does not have to accept a โlegal conclusion 
8  couched as a factual allegation.โ  Id.  โThreadbare recitals of the elements of a cause of action, 
9  supported by mere conclusory statements, do not suffice.โ  Id.; Jones v. Community Development 
10  Agency, 733 F.2d 646, 649 (9th Cir. 1984) (vague and mere conclusory allegations unsupported 
11  by facts are not sufficient to state section 1983 claims); Pena v. Gardner, 976 F.2d 469, 471 (9th 
12  Cir. 1992).   
13  When ruling on a motion to dismiss, the court โaccept[s] all factual allegations in the 
14  complaint as true and constru[es] them in the light most favorable to 
15  the nonmoving party.โ  Fields v. Twitter, 881 F.3d 739, 743 (9th Cir. 2018).  Furthermore, in 
16  general, pro se pleadings are held to a less stringent standard than those drafted by attorneys and 
17  the court is obligated, particularly in civil rights cases, to construe such pleadings liberally and 
18  afford the pro se party any benefit of the doubt.  See Garmon v. County of Los Angeles, 828 F.3d 
19  837, 846 (9th Cir. 2016); Bretz v. Kelman, 773 F.2d 1026, 1027 n. 1 (9th Cir. 1985) (en banc). 
20  That said, the courtโs liberal construction of a pro se complaint may not supply essential 
21  elements of the claim that were not pled.  Ivey v. Bd. of Regents of Univ. of Alaska, 673 F.2d 266, 
22  268 (9th Cir. 1982).

2  b.  Motion to Amend 
3  Pursuant to Fed. R. Civ. P. 15(a), at this point in the litigation, a Plaintiff โmay amend 
4  [his] pleading only by leave of the court or by written consent of the adverse party; and leave 
5  shall be freely given when justice so requires.โ  In determining whether to allow an amendment 
6  to a complaint Courts consider the following factors: โthe presence or absence of undue delay, 
7  bad faith, dilatory motive, undue prejudice to the opposing party, and futility of the proposed 
8  amendment.โ  Moore v. Kayport Package Express, Inc., 885 F.2d 531, 538 (9th Cir. 1989).   
9  โPrejudice is the touchstone of the inquiry under rule 15(a) ... Absent prejudice, or a 
10  strong showing of any of the remaining [above] factors, there exists a presumption under Rule 
11  15(a) in favor of granting leave to amend.โ  Eminence Capital, LLC v. Aspeon, Inc., 316 F.3d 
12  1048, 1052 (9th Cir. 2003) (internal quotation marks and citation omitted).  
13  โThe party opposing [the] amendment bears the burden of showing prejudice, unfair delay, bad 
14  faith, or futility of amendment.โ  United Steel, Paper & Forestry, Rubber, Mfg., Energy, Allied 
15  Indus. & Serv. Workers Int'l Union, AFL-CIO, CLC v. ConocoPhillips Co., 2009 WL 650730, at 
16  *2 (C.D. Cal. Mar. 12, 2009) (citing Eminence Capital, 316 F.3d at 1052; DCD Programs, Ltd. 
17  v. Leighton, 833 F.2d 183, 186-87 (9th Cir. 1987)).  Undue delay alone is generally insufficient 
18  to justify denying a motion to amend under Rule 15.  See Bowles v. Reade, 198 F.3d 752, 758 
19  (9th Cir. 1999).  Further, โ[a] proposed amendment is futile only if no set of facts can be proved 
20  under the amendment to the pleading that would constitute a valid and sufficient claim or 
21  defense.โ  Miller v. Rykoff-Sexton, Inc., 845 F.2d 209, 214 (9th Cir. 1988) (abrogated on other 
22  grounds by Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 556 U.S. 662 (2009)).

2  c.  Conditions of Confinement - Eighth Amendment 
3  The Eighth Amendmentโs prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment protects 
4  prisoners from inhumane conditions of confinement.  Morgan v. Morgensen, 465 F.3d 1041, 
5  1045 (9th Cir. 2006).  Prison officials therefore have a โduty to ensure that prisoners are 
6  provided adequate shelter, food, clothing, sanitation, medical care, and personal safety.โ  
7  Johnson v. Lewis, 217 F.3d 726, 731 (9th Cir. 2000) (citations omitted).  To establish a violation 
8  of this duty, a prisoner must show that he was subjected to an objectively serious deprivation that 
9  amounts to a denial of โthe minimal civilized measure of lifeโs necessities.โ  Farmer v. Brennan, 
10  511 U.S. 825, 834 (1994) (quoting Rhodes v. Chapman, 452 U.S. 337, 346 (1981)).  A prisoner 
11  must also show that prison officials acted with sufficiently culpable states of mind in failing to 
12  satisfy their duties.  Id.  Prison officials must have acted with deliberate indifference.  Id.  A 
13  prison official is liable under the Eighth Amendment only if he or she โknows of and disregards 
14  an excessive risk to inmate health or safety; the official must both be aware of facts from which 
15  the inference could be drawn that a substantial risk of serious harm exists, and he [or she] must 
16  also draw the inference.โ  Id. at 837 
17  d.  Conditions of Confinement โ Fourteenth Amendment 
18  In contrast to post-conviction prisoners, pretrial detainees have the right to be free from 
19  punishment under the Fourteenth Amendment.  Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 533 (1979).  In 
20  assessing conditions of confinement for pretrial detainees, the Court considers whether the 
21  conditions amount to punishment, causing harm or disability significantly exceeding or 
22  independent of the inherent discomforts of confinement, or whether they merely result from 
23  some legitimate governmental purpose.  See Doe v. Kelly, 878 F.3d 710, 714, 720 (9th Cir.

1  2017).  The Court evaluates a pretrial detaineeโs Fourteenth Amendment claim under an 
2  objective deliberate indifference standard.  See Gordon v. County of Orange, 888 F.3d 1118, 
3  1124-25 (9th Cir. 2018) (applying objective standard to medical care claims and describing 
4  similar treatment afforded medical care and other conditions of confinement claims) (citing 
5  Kingsley v. Hendrickson, 576 U.S. 389, 135 S. Ct. 2466, 2475, 192 L. Ed. 2d 416 (2015), and 
6  Castro v. County of Los Angeles, 833 F.3d 1060, 1070 (9th Cir. 2016), cert. denied, 137 S. Ct. 
7  831, 97 L. Ed. 2d 69 (2017)).4   
8  A pretrial detainee must demonstrate a defendantโs acts or omissions were objectively 
9  unreasonable, and identify objective facts indicating the โchallenged governmental action is not 
10  rationally related to a legitimate governmental objective or that it is excessive in relation to that 
11  [objective].โ  Kingsley, 576 U.S. at 398.  The elements of a pretrial detaineeโs claim against an 
12  individual defendant under the objective deliberate indifference standard are as follows:  
13  (i) the defendant made an intentional decision with respect to the conditions under which 
the plaintiff was confined; (ii) those conditions put the plaintiff at substantial risk of 
14  suffering serious harm; (iii) the defendant did not take reasonable available measures to 
abate that risk, even though a reasonable official in the circumstances would have 
appreciated the high degree of risk involvedโmaking the consequences of the 
15 
defendantโs conduct obvious; and (iv) by not taking such measures, the defendant caused 
the plaintiffโs injuries. 
16 
 
Id. at 1125.  โWith respect to the third element, the defendantโs conduct must be objectively 
17 
unreasonable, a test that will necessarily โturn[ ] on the facts and circumstances of each particular 
18

11  Amendment and, by extension, are also sufficient to meet the objective deliberate indifference 
12  standard under the Fourteenth Amendment. 
13  In sum, the Court finds that, whether analyzed under the Eighth Amendment or 
14  Fourteenth Amendment standard, Plaintiff has sufficiently stated a claim in his proposed second 
15  amended complaint against Defendants Sutherlin, Dobson, Herbison, Pearson, and Mastandrea 
16  based upon the conditions of his confinement.  Accordingly, the Court recommends that, with 
17  respect to the individual capacity federal claims against these Defendants, Defendantsโ motion to 
18  dismiss should denied and Plaintiffโs motion to amend should be granted. 
19  b.  Individual Capacity Federal Claims Against Defendants Patti Jackson and 
Ed Troyer 
20   
With respect to the individual capacity federal constitutional claims against Defendants 
21 
Patti Jackson and Ed Troyer, the Court finds that Defendants have shown that Plaintiff fails to 
22 
state a claim either in his amended complaint or his proposed second amended complaint 
23 
whether analyzed under the Eighth or Fourteenth Amendment standard.  As such, Defendantsโ 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 23 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 24 of 35
 
1  motion to dismiss should be granted and Plaintiffโs motion to amend denied as futile with respect 
2  to the individual capacity federal constitutional claims against Defendants Patti Jackson and Ed 
3  Troyer.   
4  In order to state a claim for relief under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983, a plaintiff must show: (1) he 
5  suffered a violation of rights protected by the Constitution or created by federal statute, and (2) 
6  the violation was proximately caused by a person acting under color of state law.  See Crumpton 
7  v. Gates, 947 F.2d 1418, 1420 (9th Cir. 1991).  The first step in a ยง 1983 claim is therefore to 
8  identify the specific constitutional right allegedly infringed.  Albright v. Oliver, 510 U.S. 266, 
9  271 (1994).  
10  To satisfy the second prong, a plaintiff must allege facts showing how individually 
11  named defendants caused, or personally participated in causing, the harm alleged in the 
12  complaint.  See Leer v. Murphy, 844 F.2d 628, 633 (9th Cir. 1988); Arnold v. IBM, 637 F.2d 
13  1350, 1355 (9th Cir. 1981).  A person subjects another to a deprivation of a constitutional right 
14  when committing an affirmative act, participating in anotherโs affirmative act, or omitting to 
15  perform an act which is legally required.  Johnson v. Duffy, 588 F.2d 740, 743 (9th Cir. 1978). 
16  Sweeping conclusory allegations against an official are insufficient to state a claim for relief.  Leer, 
17  844 F.2d at 633.  Further, a ยง 1983 suit cannot be based on vicarious liability alone, but must allege 
18  the defendantโs own conduct violated the plaintiffโs civil rights.  City of Canton v. Harris, 489 U.S. 
19  378, 385-90 (1989).  Thus, โ[a] supervisor is only liable for the constitutional violations of โฆ 
20  subordinates if the supervisor participated in or directed the violations, or knew of the violations 
21  and failed to act to prevent them.โ  Taylor v. List, 880 F.2d 1040, 1045 (9th Cir. 1989) (citations 
22  omitted) 
23 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 24 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 25 of 35
 
1  โA showing that a supervisor acted, or failed to act, in a manner that was deliberately 
2  indifferent to an inmateโs Eighth Amendment rights is sufficient to demonstrate the involvement 
3  โ and the liability โ of that supervisor.  Thus, when a supervisor is found liable based on 
4  deliberate indifference, the supervisor is being held liable for his or her own culpable action or 
5  inaction, not held vicariously liable for the culpable action or inaction of his or her 
6  subordinates.โ  Starr v. Baca, 652 F.3d 1202, 1207 (9th Cir. 2011) (holding that โa plaintiff may 
7  state a claim against a supervisor for deliberate indifference based upon the supervisorโs 
8  knowledge of and acquiescence in unconstitutional conduct by his or her subordinatesโ). 
9  Here, Plaintiffโs individual capacity federal claims against Defendants Jackson and 
Troyer in both the amended complaint and proposed second amended complaint appear to be 
10 
based primarily upon the theory of vicarious liability.  Specifically, Plaintiff alleges Defendant 
11 
Troyer,  
12 
[i]s and was the Sheriff of Pierce County, and in that Capacity is and was Responsible for 
13 
establishing or Failing To Establish the Policies, Practices, and Regulations for the 
conduct of the Pierce County Sheriff Department and its Employees.   
14 
Defendant โฆ Troyer is and was Responsible for the hiring, training, supervision, 
discipline, and control of all members of the Pierce County Sheriffโs department.  
15 
Defendant County Sheriff is and was the Commanding Officer of the other Police 
personnel named herein as individual Defendants. 
16  [โฆ] 
Defendant County Sheriff has a Constitutional and Statutory responsibility for the 
17  Conditions and Practices of the Pierce County Jail Facility and โฆ is responsible for 
maintaining the Jail facility in conformity with Constitutional requisites.  Defendant โฆ is 
also Custodian of the Jail Facility, responsible for the Neglect and Omission of the duties 
18 
of all Deputy Sheriffs and Corrections Officers, and Charged with Furnishing necessary 
Sanitation, Bedding, Clothing, Medical Aid, and Mental Health Social Workers for all 
19 
persons detained in the Jail Facility.   
In addition, Defendant โฆ is and was responsible for ensuring that the Deputy Sheriff and 
20 
Corrections Officers of Pierce County Sheriff Dept. Obeyed regulations of the Pierce 
County Sheriffโs Department, the Ordinance and Law of Pierce County, and the Laws 
21  and Constitution of the State of Washington and the United States. 
Defendant โฆ is and was Responsible for the Establishment, Policies, Procedures and 
22  guidelines for the Arrest, Jailing and Safe Keeping of Pre-trial Detainees.  
 
23  Dkt. 53-2, at 7.  Plaintiff alleges, 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 25 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 26 of 35
 
1  Defendant Jackson is and was the Chief of the Internal Operation of the Sheriff Dept. 
Correction Bureau, and in that Capacity, is and was Constitutionally and Statutorily 
2  responsible also for the Training, Supervision, Discipline, and Control of all Deputy 
Correction Officers, as well as the Operation, Practices, and Totality of Conditions of the 
Pierce County Jail Facility.  Defendant Chief has Statutory Responsibility also for 
3 
ensuring that the Pierce County Jail Facility conforms to the requirements of State Law, 
and the Laws and Constitution of the United States.  In addition, defendant Chief is and 
4 
was Responsible for the establishment of Policies, procedures, and Guidelines for the 
Arrest, Jailing, and Safe Keeping of Pre-Trial detainees housed in the Pierce County Jail 
5 
Facility.  
 
6  Dkt. 53-2, at 8.   
7  Plaintiff fails to allege sufficient facts to show Defendants Troyer and Jackson were 
8  personally aware of the plumbing and sewer issue or what specific actions or inactions by these 
9  Defendants constituted deliberate indifference.  With respect to Defendant Jackson, Plaintiff 
10  does allude to the existence of an email with her name on it that discussed flushing the toilets in 
11  the empty cells in the unit.  But Plaintiff provides no facts to indicate what issue the instruction 
12  in the email was intended to address, or to indicate that Defendant Jackson was personally aware 
13  of the nature or extent of the conditions Plaintiff alleges in his proposed second amended 
14  complaint.  As such, Plaintiffโs conclusory allegations are insufficient to show these Defendants 
15  personally participated in the alleged constitutional violations.  See Jones v. Community 
16  Development Agency, 733 F.2d 646, 649 (9th Cir. 1984) (vague and mere conclusory allegations 
17  unsupported by facts are not sufficient to state section 1983 claims).  
18  Accordingly, the Court recommends that, with respect to the individual capacity federal 
19  claims against Defendants Troyer and Jackson, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss should granted, 
20  Plaintiffโs motion to amend should be denied, and these claims should be dismissed without 
21  prejudice. 
22  c.  Federal Claims Against Pierce County 
23  With respect to Defendant Pierce County, Plaintiff alleges he was informed repeatedly by 
  Jail officials, including several of the individual Defendants, that Pierce County was aware of the 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 26 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 27 of 35
 
1  plumbing conditions at the Jail and that they would not be fixing anything at that time.  The 
2  Court finds that, whether analyzed under the Eighth Amendment or Fourteenth Amendment 
3  standard, Plaintiff has set forth sufficient factual allegations in his proposed second amended 
4  complaint to state a claim against Defendant Pierce County, based upon the conditions of his 
5  confinement.  The Court notes that while it appears the claims in Plaintiffโs amended complaint 
6  against Defendant Pierce County were sufficient, even assuming some of those claims were 
7  insufficient, Defendants have failed to demonstrate that Plaintiff has failed to state a claim in his 
8  proposed second amended complaint, or that amendment of the complaint is futile.6   
9  A local governmental unit may not be held responsible for the acts of its employees under 
10  a respondeat superior theory of liability.  See Bd. of Cty. Commโrs v. Brown, 520 U.S. 397, 403 
11  (1997); Monell v. Depโt of Soc. Servs., 436 U.S. 658, 691 (1978).  โTo [prevail on a claim against 
12  a municipal entity for a constitutional violation], a plaintiff must go beyond the respondeat 
13  superior theory of liability and demonstrate that the alleged constitutional deprivation was the 
14  product of a policy or custom of the local governmental unit.โ  Kirkpatrick v. Cty. of Washoe, 
15  843 F.3d 784, 793 (9th Cir. 2016) (en banc).  Municipal liability must rest on the actions of the 
16  municipality, and not the actions of its employees.  See Brown, 520 U.S. at 403; Monell, 436 
17  U.S. at 690โ91; Fogel, 531 F.3d at 834.  โMunicipal liability may be premised upon: (1) conduct 
18  pursuant to an expressly adopted official policy; (2) a longstanding practice or custom which 
19  constitutes the โstandard operating procedureโ of the local government entity; (3) a decision of a 
20  decision-making official who was, as a matter of law, a final policymaking authority whose 
21  edicts or acts may fairly be said to represent official policy in the area of decision; or (4) an 
22 
 
23 
6 The Court notes that Defendants again do not appear to argue that any of the other factors support denial of the 
motion to amend, nor does the Court find that these other factors (undue delay, bad faith, dilatory motive, or undue 
  prejudice) would support denial of leave to amend here. 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 27 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 28 of 35
 
1  official with final policymaking authority either delegating that authority to, or ratifying the 
2  decision of, a subordinate.โ  Young v. City of Visalia, 687 F.Supp.2d 1141, 1147 (E.D.Cal. 2009) 
3  (internal citations omitted).   
4  A โcustomโ for purposes of municipal liability is a โwidespread practice that, although 
5  not authorized by written law or express municipal policy, is so permanent and well-settled as to 
6  constitute a custom or usage with the force of law.โ  See City of St. Louis v. Praprotnik, 485 U.S. 
7  112, 127, 108 S.Ct. 915, 99 L.Ed.2d 107 (1988); L.A. Police Protective League v. Gates, 907 
8  F.2d 879, 890 (9th Cir. 1990).  Allegations of random acts, or single instances of misconduct, 
9  however, are insufficient to establish a municipal custom.  See Navarro v. Block, 72 F.3d 712, 
10  714 (9th Cir. 1996).  Liability โmust be founded upon practices of sufficient duration, frequency 
11  and consistency that the conduct has become a traditional method of carrying out 
12  policy.โ  Trevino v. Gates, 99 F.3d 911, 918 (9th Cir. 1996); see also McDade v. West, 223 F.3d 
13  1135, 1141 (9th Cir. 2000).  Once the plaintiff has demonstrated that a custom existed, a 
14  โmunicipality may be liable for its custom โirrespective of whether official policymakers had 
15  actual knowledge of the practice at issue.โโ  Navarro v. Block, 72 F.3d 712, 714โ15 (9th Cir. 
16  1995) (quoting Thompson v. City of Los Angeles, 885 F.2d 1439, 1444 (9th Cir.1989)); but 
17  see Blair v. City of Pomona, 223 F.3d 1074, 1080 (9th Cir. 2000) (โopen to the [municipality] to 
18  show that the custom was not known to the policy-makersโ).  A plaintiff โmust show that the 
19  challenged municipal conduct was both the cause in fact and the proximate cause of the 
20  constitutional deprivation.โ  Young, 687 F.Supp.2d at 1148. 
21  Plaintiff alleges that Defendant Pierce County violated Eighth and Fourteenth 
22  Amendment constitutional standards by subjecting him to a severe and persistent backflushing 
23  problem and other sewer issues at Pierce County Jail and refusing to provide him with cleaning 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 28 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 29 of 35
 
1  supplies to clean and sanitize areas contaminated by wastewater.  Construing the allegations in 
2  the light most favorable to Plaintiff, he has sufficiently alleged that Defendant Pierce County 
3  maintained a custom of allowing the backflushing and sewer issue to continue and refusing to 
4  provide cleaning supplies.  
5  Plaintiff alleges that he was incarcerated in the 3 North A unit for approximately seven 
6  months and that throughout this time there was a backflushing problem such that when the 
7  inmates in other cells flushed their toilet the waste would backflush into the toilet in Plaintiffโs 
8  cell and that the wastewater would often splash onto the seat of his toilet or onto the floor of his 
9  cell.  Plaintiff claims that he and other inmates were denied cleaning supplies to sanitize the area 
10  contaminated by the backflushing and that he had to clean the contaminated areas of his cell with 
11  his own T-shirt. 
12  Plaintiff alleges that he asked various Jail officials, including several individually named 
13  Defendants, on numerous occasions to fix the plumbing issue, but that they responded that the 
14  issue was structural, that Pierce County was aware of the issue and that it would not be fixed at 
15  that time, and that Plaintiff would just have to deal with it.   As discussed above, as is the case 
16  here, โa backflushing problem, at least when accompanied by a refusal to provide cleaning 
17  supplies โฆ, amounts to a violation of Eighth Amendment principles.โ  Bodnar, 2014 WL 
18  2737815, at *7โ9, report and recommendation adopted, 2014 WL 2741070; Cockcroft, 548 
19  F.Supp.2d at 774โ76.  
20  Plaintiff contends that the backflushing and sanitation problems were the result of a 
21  custom or municipal policy.  The Court finds Plaintiff has alleged sufficient facts to support a 
22  claim that Defendant Pierce County maintained a custom of allowing the backflushing problem 
23  while denying cleaning supplies.  Specifically, Plaintiff has presented evidence that this was a 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 29 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 30 of 35
 
1  prolonged issue at Pierce County Jail, that many inmates were aware of the problem and 
2  complained, and that each member of the staff notified of the problem did essentially nothing to 
3  remedy the situation (or at least nothing legitimately intended to resolve it) and that Plaintiff was 
4  consistently denied cleaning supplies when he requested them.  In fact, according to Plaintiff, 
5  several Jail officials, including several individually named Defendants, acknowledged that this 
6  was a โ30-year old problemโ, that Pierce County would not fix it at that time, and the unit 
7  residents would โjust have to deal with it.โ  Plaintiff further alleges that he was informed by Jail 
8  officials that cleaning supplies were not a policy but a โprivilegeโ for the cluster officers to give 
9  at their disposal and that he was informed on another occasion that Pierce County had no specific 
10  policy requiring the provision of cleaning supplies to inmates.  Id.  Plaintiff has alleged sufficient 
11  facts to support a claim that it was the custom to deny cleaning supplies when requested by unit 
12  residents.  The Court finds these allegations are sufficient to indicate that Defendant maintained 
13  a โwidespread practice that, although not authorized by written law or express municipal policy, 
14  is so permanent and well settled as to constitute a custom or usage with the force of 
15  law.โ  Praprotnik, 485 U.S. at 127.  Plaintiff has also sufficiently alleged that this custom was 
16  the cause-in-fact and legal cause of the alleged constitutional deprivation.   
17  In sum, the Court finds that, whether analyzed under the Eighth Amendment or 
18  Fourteenth Amendment standard, Plaintiff has sufficiently stated a claim in his proposed second 
19  amended complaint against Defendant Pierce County based upon the conditions of his 
20  confinement.  Accordingly, the Court recommends that, with respect to the federal claims against 
21  Defendant Pierce County, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss should denied and Plaintiffโs motion to 
22  amend should be granted. 
23  d.  Official Capacity Claims against All Defendants 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 30 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 31 of 35
 
1  Plaintiff also sues all non-entity Defendants in their official capacities.  An action against 
2  a municipal officer in an official capacity is equivalent to an action against the local government 
3  entity.  See Kentucky v. Graham, 473 U.S. 159, 165-66 (1985) (โOfficial-capacity suits... 
4  โgenerally represent only another way of pleading an action against an entity of which an officer 
5  is an agent.โโ) (quoting Monell, 436 U.S. at 690 n.55); Larez v. City of Los Angeles, 946 F.2d 
6  630, 646 (9th Cir. 1991) (โA suit against a governmental officer in his official capacity is 
7  equivalent to a suit against the government entity itself.โ).  In their motion to dismiss, 
8  Defendants argue that Plaintiff has failed to establish that a policy of the local government entity, 
9  Pierce County, caused the constitutional deprivation.  Dkt. 33, at 9-10.  However, as discussed 
above, the Court has separately concluded that Plaintiff has, in fact, alleged sufficient facts to 
10 
proceed with his federal claims against the local entity, Pierce County.  Specifically, the Court 
11 
has concluded that Plaintiff has sufficiently alleged that Pierce County maintained a custom of 
12 
allowing the backflushing and sewer issue to continue and refusing to provide cleaning supplies, 
13 
and that this was the cause of the constitutional deprivation Plaintiff alleges.   
14 
In the absence of any other specific substantive arguments made by Defendants with 
15 
respect to Plaintiffโs official capacity claims, the Court finds that Plaintiff has arguably stated 
16 
enough facts to go forward with these claims against all individual Defendants at this time, and 
17 
the Court cannot conclude that inclusion of these claims in the second amended complaint would 
18 
be futile.7  
19 
20 
21 
22 
 
23 
7 The Court notes that Defendants again do not appear to argue that any of the other factors support denial of the 
motion to amend, nor does the Court find that these other factors (undue delay, bad faith, dilatory motive, or undue 
  prejudice) would support denial of leave to amend here. 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 31 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 32 of 35
 
1  Accordingly, the Court recommends that Defendantsโ motion to dismiss be denied and 
2  Plaintiffโs motion to amend be granted with respect to his official capacity claims against all 
3  individual Defendants. 
4  e.  State Law Claims against All Defendants 
5  Plaintiffโs proposed second amended complaint also alleges new state law claims of 
6  negligence, โministerial negligenceโ, and violation of the Washington State Constitution, against 
7  all Defendants.  These claims were not included in Plaintiffโs amended complaint and, as such, 
8  Defendants did not address them in their motion to dismiss which was directed to the amended 
9  complaint.  Defendants oppose Plaintiffโs motion to amend to include these claims in the 
proposed second amended complaint but do so only in a conclusory fashion, primarily based on 
10 
their position that Plaintiff has failed to state a federal constitutional violation (which the Court 
11 
has largely rejected), and without addressing the specific requirements necessary to state a claim 
12 
with respect to these state law claims.  In the absence of any substantive or non-conclusory 
13 
arguments made by Defendants with respect to Plaintiffโs state law claims in opposing Plaintiffโs 
14 
motion to amend, the Court cannot conclude that inclusion of Plaintiffโs state law claims would 
15 
be futile8 and finds that Plaintiff has arguably stated enough facts to go forward with his state 
16 
law claims against all Defendants at this time.   
17 
Accordingly, the Court recommends that Plaintiffโs motion to amend be granted with 
18 
respect to his state law claims against all Defendants. 
19 
// 
20 
// 
21 
22 
 
23 
8 The Court notes that Defendants again do not appear to argue that any of the other factors support denial of the 
motion to amend, nor does the Court find that these other factors (undue delay, bad faith, dilatory motive, or undue 
  prejudice) would support denial of leave to amend here. 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 32 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 33 of 35
 
1  B.  Motion to Change Venue 
2  Defendants also move to change venue to the Tacoma division of the U.S. District Court 
3  for the Western District of Washington.  Dkt. 33. 
4  Pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1404(a), a district court may transfer an action to 
5  a different district or division โ[f]or the convenience of parties and witnessesโ and โin the 
6  interest of justice,โ so long as the action could have been filed in the transferee district or 
7  division in the first instance.  28 U.S.C. ยง 1404(a); see Sparling v. Hoffman Construction 
8  Company, Inc., 864 F.2d 635, 639 (9th Cir. 1988) (citing id.) (quotation marks omitted).  
9  District courts have โbroad discretionโ in deciding whether to grant a Section 1404(a) motion to 
10  transfer venue.  Commodity Futures Trading Commission v. Savage, 611 F.2d 270, 279 (9th Cir. 
11  1979).  The moving party bears the burden to establish that a venue transfer โwill allow a case to 
12  proceed more conveniently and better serve the interests of justice.โ  Rubio v. Monsanto Co., 181 
13  F. Supp. 3d 746, 759-60 (C.D. Cal. Mar. 24, 2016); Hunter v. Haar, No. CV 14-9886 R(JC), 
14  2016 WL 11520384, at *1 (C.D. Cal. Dec. 7, 2016). 
15  The Court first notes that this case was filed as and is still designated a Tacoma division 
16  case but was assigned by the courtโs random district-wide assignment procedures to a Seattle 
17  District Court Judge and Magistrate Judge.  The assignment of a Tacoma division case to Seattle 
18  judges, in and of itself, would not appear to serve as a valid basis for a motion to change venue.  
19  Even if it did, Defendants fail to show at this juncture that traveling the approximately 35 miles 
20  to the Seattle Courthouse, in the event the parties were required to personally appear for a 
21  proceeding, would significantly inconvenience to the parties or witnesses, or would otherwise 
22  implicate interests of justice concerns.  The Court also notes that there are no proceedings 
23  currently scheduled that require the physical appearance of any of the parties nor is it clear at this 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 33 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 34 of 35
 
1  point whether and when any such in-person proceedings may be required in the future.  Thus, 
2  any specific concerns about any asserted hardship in traveling to Seattle are better raised at a 
3  point in time where such travel might, in fact, be required.   
4  Accordingly, Plaintiff's motion to change venue (Dkt. 33) should be denied. 
5  CONCLUSION 
6  The Court recommends that Defendantsโ motion to dismiss (Dkts. 33, 47) and Plaintiffโs 
7  motion for leave to file a second amended complaint (Dkt. 53) be GRANTED IN PART and 
8  DENIED IN PART.  Specifically, with respect to the individual capacity federal constitutional 
9  claims against Defendants Sutherlin, Dobson, Herbison, Pearson, and Mastandrea, Defendantsโ 
10  motion to dismiss (Dkts. 33, 47) should be DENIED and Plaintiffโs motion to amend (Dkt. 53) 
11  should be GRANTED.  With respect to the individual capacity federal constitutional claims 
12  against Defendants Patti Jackson and Ed Troyer, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss (Dkts. 33, 47) 
13  should be GRANTED, Plaintiffโs motion to amend (Dkt. 53) should be DENIED, and these 
14  claims should be DISMISSED WITHOUT PREJUDICE.  With respect to the federal 
15  constitutional claims against Defendant Pierce County, Defendantsโ motion to dismiss (Dkts. 33, 
16  47) should be DENIED and Plaintiffโs motion to amend (Dkt. 53) should be GRANTED.  With 
17  respect to Plaintiffโs official capacity claims against all individual Defendants, Defendantsโ 
18  motion to dismiss (Dkts. 33, 47) should be DENIED and Plaintiffโs motion to amend (Dkt. 53) 
19  should be GRANTED.  And, with respect to Plaintiffโs state law claims against all Defendants, 
20  Plaintiffโs motion to amend (Dkt. 53) should be GRANTED.  The Court further recommends that 
21  Defendantsโ motion to change venue (Dkt. 33) be DENIED.  A proposed order accompanies this 
22  Report and Recommendation. 
23 
 
 
REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION - 34 
 

Case 3:21-cv-05068-LK-SKV     Document 66     Filed 03/10/22     Page 35 of 35

Do not use this form if you are challenging the validity of your criminal conviction or
your criminal sentence. If you are challenging your conviction or sentence, or if you are seeking
restoration of good-time credits that would shorten your sentence, you must file a Petition for
Writ of Habeas Corpus. If you use this form to challenge your conviction or sentence, you risk

2. 
Under the Prison Litigation Reform Act ("PLRA"), you are required to exhaust all
remedies in your institution's grievance system that are available to you before filing suit. This
generally means that you must file a grievance and, if it is denied, appeal it through all available
levels of review. Your case may be dismissed if you fail to exhaust administrative remedies,
unless the administrative grievance process was not "available" to you within the meaning of the
PLRA. You are not required to plead or show that you have exhausted your claim in this
complaint.

L.t32l Defendants Pierce County, Ed Troyer, and PattiJackson, B. Sutherlin, Dobson, D. Herbison,

1.135) WHEREFORE, Plaintiff request this Court to:
a. Declare that subjecting the Plaintiff to the conditions described herein violates the Eighth and
Fourteenth Amendments to the United States Constitution and the Due Process Clause of the
Washington State Constitution and constitutes negligence and ministerial negligence under Washington
State law.
b. Enjoin Defendants, and their successors, from subjecting the men in the PCJ to unsanitary, unhealthy,
and unsafe conditions, and require that a remedy be formulated, subject to the Court's approval and
modification,  if necessary, to end the inhumane conditions at the PCJ.
c. Award Plaintiff Davey who was exposed to the conditions described herein at the PCJ reasonable
actual and compensatory damages of S2,000 (Dollars) Per Day that Plaintiff was held in said conditions
against each Defendant, jointly and severally, to compensate Plaintiff for the deprivation of his
constitutional rights and all consequences thereof.
d. Award Plaintiff who was exposed to the conditions at the PCJ described herein reasonabte punitive
damages of the amount of 52,000 (Dollars) Per Day that Plaintiff was held in said conditions against each
of the individual Defendants.
e. Award Plaintiff who was exposed to the conditions at the PCJ described herein damages for the
denials of their right to be free from cruel and unusual punishment and right to due process.
f. Retain jurisdiction in this case until the unlawful conditions, practices, policies, acts, and omissions
complained of herein no longer exist and this Court is satisfied that they will not recur.
g. Plaintiff Seeks a Jury Trial on all issues triable by Jury
